results.notes: Group of three fungi joined in cluster. When these images were taken (in Eucalyptus rainforest.), I noticed that the stipes changed colour when the fungi had been removed from its original location in soil. The stipes in the first image have a green tint, whereas the 2nd image shows a more blue tint. The fungi was moved slightly to display the gills, causing the dilemma. I am not sure which colour is correct as both images are white balanced to the same light conditions. The Gills are moderately wide and yellow.

results.notes:
Growing on the underside of a mossy very well rotted hardwood (?) log near Quercus spp., Acer sp., Fagus grandifolia, Liriodendron tulipifera, Tsuga canadensis and likely some smaller hardwoods. All structures inamyloid. Monomitic with hyphae appearing predominantly clamped. Some hymenial hyphae short-celled.Large, tubular, thick-walled cystidia present. Cystidia of tramal origin. Some cystidia encrusted with crystals along the sides. Cystidia up to 168.8 µm long and 7.3 µm wide, projecting up to 61.5 µm. Hyphidia absent. Basidia 4-sterigmate and terminal, 14 – 22.06 (22.1) × (4.6) 4.63 – 5.3 µm (3 measured). Sterigmata measured at between 1.8 and 2.7 µm long. Spores smooth and thin walled. Spore measurements from Piximetre: (5.1) 5.2 – 6.1 (6.5) × (2.8) 3 – 3.7 (3.9) µm, Q = (1.6) 1.61 – 1.78 (1.8); N = 10, Me = 5.7 × 3.4 µm; Qe = 1.7
Individual spores: 6.11 × 3.73 µm, 6.01 × 3.34 µm, 5.67 × 3.62 µm, 5.59 × 3.18 µm, 6.50 × 3.89 µm, 5.22 × 2.97 µm, 5.32 × 3.30 µm, 5.74 × 3.38 µm, 5.63 × 3.43 µm, 5.07 × 2.84 µm

results.notes:
This was collected from an old railroad tie fence post around a small spring in an otherwise large expanse of semi-arid grassland.

The lichen is sterile, lacking apothecia, and also lacks soredia. The Thallus is crustose, thick, continuous-rimose, dirty-white, with negative spot tests K-, C-, KC-. There is no UV reaction on thallus or spot tests. It does has abundant pycnidia that are black and can often resemble somewhat contorted apothecia. However, all that were sectioned turned out to be pycnidia. The bases of the pycnidia have a charcoal black cushion that extends up the side wall a bit, and the top of reddish brown. Conidia are bacilliform and of two size classes, one shorter and one longer: 5.6-7.9 × 1.6-2.4 and 12.0-13.0 × 2.4-2.7µm.

At first I thought this was a damaged Thelomma, but I didn’t find any reference to pycnidia for the genus. I didn’t get anywhere in the sterile lichen keys unfortunately.
results.location_name: Monterey Co., California, USA

results.notes:
On hardwood in deciduous floodplain forest. Soft and watery, more brownish and zonate than Tyromyces chioneus, short pubescence, whitish pores bruising to buff. Noted as having “streaked” context although context not photographed. This could be interpreted as zonate, which is a characteristic know for this species according to Gilbert & Ryvarden.

Postia livens is also another possibility given the large size relative to other P. caesia complex mushrooms in North America, larger pores, and pubescence. Lack of significant blue coloration or blue staining could be due to freshness of mushrooms, although there may be a slight bluish tint.

Brownish bruising of pores isn’t noted in any descriptions of either P. livens or P. tephroleuca. But the pores of P. caesia complex specimens seen in the same area on the same day also bruised bluish almost immediately, however these were likely not P. livens.

results.notes:
Growing on the underside of a hardwood log near Fagus grandifolia, Quercus spp., Acer sp. and Tsuga canadensis. Somewhat grandinioid. All structures inamyloid. Monomitic, possibly both clamped and simple-septate generative hyphae. Supposed simple septate hyphae may have been from a different fungus on the same log. The clamped hyphae were found associated with the basidia. Cystidia and hyphidia absent. Basidia urniform and 6-sterigmate. Spores smooth, thin-walled and reniform. Spore measurements from Piximetre: (3.7) 4 – 4.4 (5.1) × (1.8) 1.9 – 2.47 (2.5) µm, Q = (1.7) 1.9 – 2.19 (2.2); N = 10, Me = 4.2 × 2.1 µm; Qe = 2
Individual spores: 4.26 × 2.47 µm, 4.06 × 1.99 µm, 4.04 × 2.10 µm, 4.41 × 2.02 µm, 4.04 × 1.99 µm, 4.00 × 1.79 µm, 5.11 × 2.52 µm, 3.71 × 1.89 µm, 4.25 × 2.06 µm, 4.03 × 2.12 µm

results.notes:
Pores narrow elongated slotlike (widths << 1 mm), walls very thin. Context tough but flexible, like leather. Upper surfaces partially covered with green algae, whitish beneath the covering of algae.

Pore walls not broken/elonagted/toothlike.

KOH orangish along white cap margin, non-reactive elsewhere.

On downed aspen wood.
results.location_name: Moon Lake State Forest Recreation Area, Pennsylvania, USA

results.notes:
Interestingly, the pore surface did not stain brown when scratched. But, if a knife point was scraped across the pore surface with force, some brown did show.

In cross-section, three thick layers of context appear (~5 mm thick), with thin layers of brown context separating them. The lower brown layer was obviously a layer of tubes. Upon closer inspection, the two upper whitish layers were seen to be composed of old tubes.

KOH black on the lower brown layer of tubes, black on the cap surface, tan spotted black on the whitish layers, and amber on the fertile surface.

On oak.

results.notes:
A beautiful, juvenile Panther cap fruiting exclusively between two very large, old growth Douglas fir trees. Soil carefully removed to show the tight collar like volva at stem base.

This State park is a veritable treasure trove for Amanita lovers. I annually collect and document A. augusta, A. novinupta, A. aprica, A. muscaria subs. flavivolvata, Amanita pachycholea(and other vaginate Amanita’s) and most commonly, as seen here members of the Amanita Pantherina clade.

Herbarium specimen dried and stored in my home herbarium for further study and sequencing for those parties interested and seeking curation.

Temp: mid 60’s/low 30’s.

results.notes:
On hardwood in floodplain forest.

I’ve ultimately decided on Antrodia heteromorpha as a tentative ID based mainly on the large and irregular pores and larger pilei. However, the two descriptions of Brunneoporus malicolus that I’ve cited also note that it can sometimes have similarly large, irregular pores.

In fact, most of the macroscopic features of these two species seem to overlap broadly, making it very difficult to tell the two apart.

I went as far as to dissect each of the descriptions that I consulted into their component parts (such as habit, dimensions, pore shape, etc.), then compare equivalent sections of each description, tallying up how many characteristics of this specimen matched with the described parameters for the species according to each description. This resulted in 22 different categories but only 15 comparable categories since some descriptions lacked parts that others contained and some characteristics of the specimen couldn’t be determined.

One of the A. heteromorpha descriptions and B. malicolus descriptions actually fit this specimen equally well, scoring 12 out of 15, while the best match out of all the descriptions scored 13.

It seems that these species are either not always possible to tell apart or that they are in need of updated descriptions. I feel that the latter is probably the case since none of the B. malicolus observations on Mushroom Observer, two of which have been confirmed as B. malicolus by ITS sequence, seem to fit the descriptions. And many of the observations for both species are extremely similar.

Or maybe I’m missing something here.

References:
Antrodia heteromorpha:
Ryvarden, L.; Gilbertson, R.L. 1993. European polypores. Part 1. Synopsis Fungorum. 6:1-387
http://www.mycobank.org/...

Spirin,V.;Vlasák,J;Niemelä,T;Miettinen,O. 2013. What is Antrodia sensu stricto?. Mycologia. 105(2):1555-1576
http://www.mycobank.org/...

Brunneoporus malicolus:
Ryvarden, L.; Gilbertson, R.L. 1993. European polypores. Part 1. Synopsis Fungorum. 6:1-387
http://www.mycobank.org/...

Spirin, V., Vlasák, J., Rivoire, B., Kotiranta, H., & Miettinen, O. (2016). Hidden diversity in the Antrodia malicola group (Polyporales, Basidiomycota). Mycological progress, 15(5), 51.

results.notes:
Growing on soil.
Diploschistes diacapsis is a very common species at this place, which is a singular point for having clay-like soil on the balconies over the Atlantic Ocean (see http://mushroomobserver.org/...). I have also found it in this area for about 5 km inland, and all my observations of this species are from this part of the country. It does not appear to be observed in many European countries and my usual reference websites do not mention it, but it is common in Spain where it is frequently mentioned in the areas of gypsum soils (especially in the east). It is said to occur in open habitats with Mediterranean to arid climate, being also frequent in the zones of the north of Africa, constituting one of the few species of lichens that inhabit in these places.
The partners commonly referred to share the habitat with D. diacapsis are:
Psora decipiens; Fulgensia fulgens; Squamarina lentigera
all existing here, as well as others of which I highlight the following:
Acarospora nodulosa (as parasite of D. diacapsis); Buellia erubescens (on shrubs); Catillaria praedicta (on shrubs); Caloplaca marina; Caloplaca teicholyta; Collema tenax; Diploicia canescens; Lecanora spp.; Ochrolechia parella; Physcia caesia; Placidium squamulosum; Solenopsora candicans; Squamarina cartilaginea; Toninia spp.;Tornabenia atlantica (on shrubs); Xanthoria calcicola.

Another common partner is Diploschistes muscorum (a known parasite of Cladonia spp. in youth), being very difficult to separate them macroscopically, which has 4 spores/ascus instead of D. diacapsis that presents 8-spored asci, the spores being similarly shaped.

I got the following dimensions for the spores:
(21) 21.7 – 26.7 (30.5) × (10.5) 10.7 – 13.1 (14.1) µm
Q = (1.8) 1.82 – 2.2 (2.3) ; N = 32
Me = 24.5 × 12.2 µm ; Qe = 2

Below I give some links where some more information of _D. diacapspsis can be found:
http://lichenportal.org/portal/taxa/index.php?taxon=64290
http://treparriscosfieldnotebook.blogspot.pt/...
http://www.biodiversidadvirtual.org/...
http://liquenesdealmeria.blogspot.pt/...
http://mundani-garden.blogspot.pt/...

results.notes:
[Kelley Point Mycoblitz 2018. A Tullis-Krstic collection.]

On underside of a fallen barkless cottonwood branch. Up to 5 mm long.

A few measured spores (8-9 × 3.5-4) are withing range of C. cornea. Note, however, that the spines are pubescent, which is not in the description. Perhaps it can be attributed to growing conditions (underside of branch laying on the ground). It also looked more white than yellow in the field.

results.notes:
[OMS Kelley Point Mycoblitz 2018. A Tullis-Krstic collection.]

On a standing dead branch (3 cm wide) of madrone.

Asci about 230×6, spores ~2 microns wide, paraphyses less than 1 micron wide, simple, occasionally forked. The upper part of hymenium does turn blue, which is a feature of S. radiata. (Not sure that the information presented suffices for this id.)

results.notes:
[OMS Kelley Point Mycoblitz 2018. A Tullis-Krstic collection.]

Found twice, growing on the underside of cottonwood branches. Covering large areas, with membranous patches up to 50 cm long.

This is a unique fungus, forming cups that can be seen growing unobstructed and scattered, then grouped together, then forming a poroid structure. Microscopy is unimpressive, but to the spec.

Apparently uncommon in the Pacific Northwest.

[OMS Kelley Point Mycoblitz 2018. A Tullis-Krstic collection.]

results.notes:
On old wood ranch fence boards near the coast, in coastal scrub habitat.

Thallus leprose with fine yellow soredia that is C+O, K+Y(ish). Apothecia flexuose, plane, pale yellowish darkening on disks, with thin margins intermittently turned up and sorediate. Epihymenium yellowish brown in thin sections, darker in thick sections, with small POL+ orange-yellow crystals that are soluble in K. White POL+ crystals streak into hymenium (did I drag those with a dull blade? Need to double check.) Amphithecium with a cortex and filled with POL+ white crystals soluble in K.

Spores simple, hyaline, ellipsoid. Average size 10.8×4.3 (n=5).

results.notes:
[OMS Kelley Point Mycoblitz 2018. A Tullis-Krstic collection.]

Growing from some rotten leaf found under turned up cottonwood log (the same that hosted Meottomyces mutans, Observation 315350). About 2 mm tall. Gills are barely visible folds.

Basidia mostly immature, ~20 × 5. A couple with sterigmata seem to be 2-spored. One spored found: 8 × 4. Pileal cysitidia up to 130 microns; caulocystidia 20-45 microns, probably longer too. No cheilocystidia.

Hemimycena crispula is an often used synonym.

Spore print weak…brownish.

Did not see any Pleurocystidia and scant Cheilocystidia which could also be basidioles.

results.notes:
Habitat: Growing in moss in a soggy flood plain in a backyard habitat (beneath sweet gum and Bradford pear trees) in Northwest Georgia (Gordon County), US.

Gill surface: Buff to warm brown, distant, slightly decurrent.

Stipe: Thin, long, warm brown, lightly fibrillose

Pileus: Small, semiglobose to planar. Dry. Warm brown with cinnamon undertones

Odor: None.

Spore print (see photos): Slightly rusty brown.

ID help is most welcome!
results.location_name: Plainville, Georgia, USA

results.notes:
Growing on rotting wood at the base of a ridge in a dense mixed hardwood/coniferous forest in NW Georgia (Gordon County), US. April 10, 2018.

Pileus: some specimens have very faint (almost nonexistent) concentric rings of cream, orange/yellow, and tan. Firm, leathery texture.

Pores: Cream with some cinnamon/brown areas. 1-3 circular to angular pores per mm. Pores have a “3D” visual effect when rotated.

Odor: Sickeningly sweet! I could smell the bagged specimens I collected for my entire hike and on the way home.

Any guidance towards an ID is much appreciated! I’m not confident with my current Trametes suaveolens ID. Does it even occur within this range?
results.location_name: Oakman, Georgia, USA
